title: More Three-Place Practice
goal: Use `lebna`, `benji`, `bajra`, and `djuno` with correct place filling.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

Four-place practice with vecnu:

vecnu — x1 sells x2 to x3 for x4

Translate to Lojban:

  1. I sell a dog to Bob. → ?
  2. Alice sells this to me. → ?

(Answers: mi vecnu la gerku la .bob., la .alis. cu vecnu ti mi)

New Material (5-7 min)

Four More Gismu

Today you'll complete the Week 4 vocabulary with four new gismu of varying complexity.

lebna — Take

lebna — x1 takes x2 from x3
Lojban x1 x2 x3 English
mi lebna la plise la .bob. I apple Bob I take an apple from Bob.
do lebna ti mi you this me You take this from me.
la .alis. cu lebna la gerku la .tam. Alice dog Tom Alice takes a dog from Tom.

Note: lebna is the opposite of dunda in a sense — one gives, the other takes.

benji — Send

benji — x1 sends x2 to x3 (from x4 via x5)

We'll focus on x1, x2, x3 for now:

Lojban x1 x2 x3 English
mi benji ti do I this you I send this to you.
la .bob. cu benji la plise la .alis. Bob apple Alice Bob sends an apple to Alice.
do benji ta mi you that me You send that to me.

bajra — Run

bajra — x1 runs on x2 using x3 with gait x4

For now, focus on x1 (the runner):

Lojban English
mi bajra I run.
la .bob. cu bajra Bob runs.
gerku cu bajra A dog runs.
do bajra sutra You run fast.

djuno — Know

djuno — x1 knows x2 (fact) about x3 by method x4

Focus on x1, x2, x3:

Lojban x1 x2 x3 English
mi djuno ti I this — I know this.
do djuno ta you that — You know that.
la .alis. cu djuno zo'e la .bob. Alice (something) Bob Alice knows (something) about Bob.

Comparing Take and Give

Gismu Direction Example
dunda x1 → x3 I give TO Bob
lebna x1 ← x3 I take FROM Bob
Gismu Direction Example
benji x1 → x3 I send TO you

Key Point

lebna (take from) and benji (send to) are three-place gismu with different directional meanings. bajra (run) and djuno (know) round out this week's vocabulary.

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Translation (Lojban → English)

  1. mi lebna la plise la .alis.
  2. la .bob. cu benji ti mi
  3. gerku cu bajra
  4. do djuno ti
  5. la .tam. cu lebna la mlatu la .meris.
Answers
  1. I take an apple from Alice.
  2. Bob sends this to me.
  3. A dog runs.
  4. You know this.
  5. Tom takes a cat from Mary.

Exercise 2: Translation (English → Lojban)

  1. I send an apple to Bob.
  2. Alice takes this from me.
  3. You run.
  4. Bob knows that.
  5. I take a dog from Tom.
Answers
  1. mi benji la plise la .bob.
  2. la .alis. cu lebna ti mi
  3. do bajra
  4. la .bob. cu djuno ta
  5. mi lebna la gerku la .tam.

Exercise 3: Mixed Practice

Create 6 sentences mixing all three-place gismu from this week:

Use: dunda, cusku, lebna, benji, vecnu

Example answers
  1. mi dunda la plise la .bob. (I give an apple to Bob)
  2. la .alis. cu cusku ti mi (Alice says this to me)
  3. do lebna la gerku la .tam. (You take a dog from Tom)
  4. mi benji ta la .meris. (I send that to Mary)
  5. la .bob. cu vecnu la mlatu do (Bob sells a cat to you)
  6. mi lebna ti la .alis. .i mi benji ti la .bob. (I take this from Alice. I send this to Bob.)

items.answer: I take an apple from Alice.
Tom takes a cat from Mary.

items.text: I send an apple to Bob.
I take a dog from Tom.

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud:

  1. "I take an apple from you." → mi lebna la plise do
  2. "Bob sends this to Alice." → la .bob. cu benji ti la .alis.
  3. "The dog runs fast." → gerku cu bajra sutra
  4. "Do you know this?" → xu do djuno ti

Today's Vocab

Lojban Place Structure English
lebna x1 takes x2 from x3 take
benji x1 sends x2 to x3 (from x4 via x5) send
bajra x1 runs on x2 using x3 with gait x4 run
djuno x1 knows x2 (fact) about x3 by method x4 know

sections.content:
Summary

You learned four more gismu: lebna (take from), benji (send to), bajra (run), and djuno (know). These complete the Week 4 vocabulary. You now have 10 new gismu that demonstrate place structures from 1 to 5 places.

Tomorrow preview: Full week review — you'll practice all place structures, use zo'e strategically, and test yourself on the complete Week 4 vocabulary.
